Uses ‚àÇ¬≤ = 0! ‚úì

Same as homology, but ‚Äúdual.‚Äù

4. Cochain Complex

Cochain complex:

\[0 \to C^0(X) \xrightarrow{\delta^0} C^1(X) \xrightarrow{\delta^1} C^2(X) \to \cdots\]

Arrows go UP in dimension (opposite of chains).

Cocycles: Z^n = ker(Œ¥^n) (cochains v·ªõi Œ¥œÜ = 0)

Coboundaries: B^n = im(Œ¥^{n-1}) (cochains = Œ¥œà)

Lemma: B^n ‚äÜ Z^n (follows from Œ¥¬≤ = 0).

üìä Cohomology Groups

1. Definition

ƒê·ªãnh nghƒ©a (Cohomology Groups):

\[H^n(X; G) = \frac{Z^n(X; G)}{B^n(X; G)} = \frac{\ker(\delta^n)}{\text{im}(\delta^{n-1})}\]

Quotient: cocycles modulo coboundaries.

Same algebraic structure as homology!

2. Properties

Abelian groups: H^n(X) always abelian.

Functorial (contravariant):
f: X ‚Üí Y induces:

\[f^* : H^n(Y) \to H^n(X) \quad \text{(reverse direction!)}\]

Construction:
œÜ: C_n(Y) ‚Üí G cochain.
Define f^*(œÜ) = œÜ ‚àò f_# (precompose with chain map).

Contravariance:

  • (f ‚àò g)^* = g^* ‚àò f^*
  • id^* = id

Opposite category behavior dari homology!

3. Homotopy Invariance

Theorem: X ‚âÉ Y ‚áí H^n(X) ‚âÖ H^n(Y).

Proof: Same as homology (dual argument). ‚úì

Cohomology = homotopy invariant.

‚≠ê Cup Product

1. Definition

Revolutionary feature: Cohomology c√≥ multiplication!

ƒê·ªãnh nghƒ©a (Cup Product):

\[\cup : H^p(X) \times H^q(X) \to H^{p+q}(X)\]

Bilinear, associative operation.

Construction (Sketch):
œÜ ‚àà C^p, œà ‚àà C^q. Define œÜ ‚à™ œà ‚àà C^{p+q} by:

\[(\phi \cup \psi)(\sigma) = \phi(\sigma|_{[v_0, \ldots, v_p]}) \cdot \psi(\sigma|_{[v_p, \ldots, v_{p+q}]})\]

Evaluate œÜ on ‚Äúfront‚Äù of simplex, œà on ‚Äúback‚Äù, multiply.

Extends to cohomology:
If œÜ, œà cocycles, then œÜ ‚à™ œà cocycle.
If œÜ coboundary, then œÜ ‚à™ œà coboundary.

Induces well-defined:
[œÜ] ‚à™ [œà] = [œÜ ‚à™ œà] ‚àà H^{p+q}(X).

2. Properties

Bilinearity: (Œ±‚ÇÅ + Œ±‚ÇÇ) ‚à™ Œ≤ = Œ±‚ÇÅ ‚à™ Œ≤ + Œ±‚ÇÇ ‚à™ Œ≤.

Associativity: (Œ± ‚à™ Œ≤) ‚à™ Œ≥ = Œ± ‚à™ (Œ≤ ‚à™ Œ≥).

Unity: 1 ‚àà H^0(X) is identity: 1 ‚à™ Œ± = Œ± ‚à™ 1 = Œ±.

Graded commutativity:

\[\alpha \cup \beta = (-1)^{pq} \beta \cup \alpha\]

(Œ± ‚àà H^p, Œ≤ ‚àà H^q)

Signs matter!

3. Ring Structure

ƒê·ªãnh nghƒ©a (Cohomology Ring):

\[H^*(X) = \bigoplus_{n=0}^\infty H^n(X)\]

with cup product ‚à™.

H^*(X) = graded commutative ring!

Much richer structure than homology groups.

Example:

For S¬≤, we‚Äôll see:
H^*(S¬≤) = ‚Ñ§[Œ±]/(Œ±¬≤) where Œ± ‚àà H¬≤(S¬≤).

Polynomial ring truncated!

üîÑ Universal Coefficient Theorem

1. Statement

Theorem (Universal Coefficient - Cohomology):

\[H^n(X; G) \cong \text{Hom}(H_n(X), G) \oplus \text{Ext}(H_{n-1}(X), G)\]

Relates cohomology to homology!

Terms:

  • Hom(A, G): Homomorphisms A ‚Üí G
  • Ext(A, G): Extension group (measures ‚Äútwisting‚Äù)

Special case: If H_n(X) free (no torsion), then:

\[H^n(X; G) \cong \text{Hom}(H_n(X), G) \cong H_n(X) \otimes G\]

(When G = ‚Ñ§, just H^n ‚âÖ H_n)

2. Example

X = S¬≤:
H‚ÇÇ(S¬≤) = ‚Ñ§ (free).

\[H^2(S^2; \mathbb{Z}) \cong \text{Hom}(\mathbb{Z}, \mathbb{Z}) \oplus \text{Ext}(0, \mathbb{Z}) \cong \mathbb{Z}\]

H^2(S¬≤) ‚âÖ H‚ÇÇ(S¬≤) ‚âÖ ‚Ñ§. ‚úì

X = ‚ÑùP¬≤:
H‚ÇÅ(‚ÑùP¬≤) = ‚Ñ§/2‚Ñ§ (torsion!).

\[H^1(\mathbb{RP}^2; \mathbb{Z}) \cong \text{Hom}(\mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}, \mathbb{Z}) \oplus \text{Ext}(H_0, \mathbb{Z})\] \[\cong 0 \oplus 0 = 0\]

But H‚ÇÅ(‚ÑùP¬≤) = ‚Ñ§/2‚Ñ§ ‚â† 0!

Torsion causes H^n ‚â† H_n!

üßÆ Examples and Computations

Example 1: Point

X = {pt}.

H_n(pt) = ‚Ñ§ (n=0), 0 (n>0).

Universal Coefficient:

\[H^n(\text{pt}) \cong H_n(\text{pt}) \cong \begin{cases} \mathbb{Z} & n = 0 \\ 0 & n > 0 \end{cases}\]

Ring: H^*(pt) = ‚Ñ§ (trivial multiplication).

Example 2: Sphere S^n

H_k(S^n) = ‚Ñ§ (k=0,n), 0 else.

Universal Coefficient:

\[H^k(S^n) \cong \begin{cases} \mathbb{Z} & k = 0, n \\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}\]

Cohomology ring:

\[H^*(S^n) \cong \mathbb{Z}[x]/(x^2), \quad x \in H^n(S^n)\]

(Generator x v·ªõi x¬≤ = 0.)

For n odd: Actually x¬≤ automatically 0 (graded commutativity).

For n even: x¬≤ = 0 by dimension (no H^{2n}(S^n)).

Example 3: Torus T¬≤

H_*(T¬≤) = ‚Ñ§, ‚Ñ§¬≤, ‚Ñ§ (n = 0,1,2).

H^*(T¬≤) = ‚Ñ§, ‚Ñ§¬≤, ‚Ñ§ (same by Universal Coefficient, no torsion).

Ring structure:

Generators: 1 ‚àà H^0, a, b ‚àà H^1, (a‚à™b) ‚àà H^2.

\[H^*(T^2) \cong \mathbb{Z}[a, b]/(a^2, b^2)\]

Exterior algebra on two generators!

Key: a ‚à™ a = 0, b ‚à™ b = 0 (graded commutativity, odd degree).
But a ‚à™ b ‚â† 0 (generates H¬≤).

Example 4: ‚ÑùP¬≤

H_*(‚ÑùP¬≤) = ‚Ñ§, ‚Ñ§/2‚Ñ§, 0.

Cohomology (‚Ñ§ coefficients):

\[H^0(\mathbb{RP}^2) = \mathbb{Z}, \quad H^1 = 0, \quad H^2 = 0\]

Torsion disappears!

Different picture: Use ‚Ñ§/2‚Ñ§ coefficients:

\[H^*(\mathbb{RP}^2; \mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}) = (\mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z})[x]/(x^3), \quad x \in H^1\]

Polynomial ring mod x¬≥!

Cup product: x ‚à™ x = x¬≤ ‚â† 0 ‚àà H¬≤(‚ÑùP¬≤; ‚Ñ§/2‚Ñ§) ‚âÖ ‚Ñ§/2‚Ñ§.

Detects non-orientability!

üß† Poincar√© Duality

1. Statement

Theorem (Poincar√© Duality):
M compact, oriented, n-manifold without boundary.

\[H^k(M; \mathbb{Z}) \cong H_{n-k}(M; \mathbb{Z})\]

Isomorphism:

\[PD : H^k(M) \xrightarrow{\cong} H_{n-k}(M)\]

‚ÄúTop homology ‚Üî bottom cohomology.‚Äù

Geometric intuition:
k-dimensional cycle Œ± in M.
Dual (n-k)-dimensional cycle Œ≤ = ‚Äúorthogonal complement.‚Äù

Intersection pairing ‚Üî cup product!

2. Example: S^n

H^k(S^n) ‚âÖ H_{n-k}(S^n):

  • k=0: H^0 = ‚Ñ§ ‚Üî H_n = ‚Ñ§ ‚úì
  • k=n: H^n = ‚Ñ§ ‚Üî H_0 = ‚Ñ§ ‚úì
  • else: 0 ‚Üî 0 ‚úì

Perfect duality!

3. Example: T¬≤

n=2:

  • H^0(T¬≤) = ‚Ñ§ ‚Üî H‚ÇÇ(T¬≤) = ‚Ñ§ ‚úì
  • H^1(T¬≤) = ‚Ñ§¬≤ ‚Üî H‚ÇÅ(T¬≤) = ‚Ñ§¬≤ ‚úì (self-dual!)
  • H^2(T¬≤) = ‚Ñ§ ‚Üî H‚ÇÄ(T¬≤) = ‚Ñ§ ‚úì

4. Non-orientable

‚ÑùP¬≤: Not orientable ‚áí Poincar√© Duality fails v·ªõi ‚Ñ§ coefficients.

Use ‚Ñ§/2‚Ñ§ coefficients: Duality holds.

üß† Fundamental Papers & References

Classic Works

  1. Henri Poincar√© - ‚ÄúAnalysis Situs‚Äù (1895)
    Introduced duality, Betti numbers

  2. Eduard ƒåech - ‚ÄúTh√©orie g√©n√©rale de l‚Äôhomologie‚Äù (1932)
    Cohomology theory

  3. Samuel Eilenberg, Norman Steenrod - ‚ÄúFoundations‚Äù (1952)
    Axiomatic cohomology

Textbooks

  1. Allen Hatcher - Algebraic Topology, ¬ß3.1: Cohomology

  2. Glen E. Bredon - Topology and Geometry, Chapter V

  3. Raoul Bott, Loring W. Tu - Differential Forms in Algebraic Topology

  4. James R. Munkres - Elements of Algebraic Topology, Chapter 5

üîó Applications and Connections

Characteristic Classes

Chern, Stiefel-Whitney, Pontryagin Classes: Cohomology classes of vector bundles. Classify bundles, detect obstructions.

Obstruction Theory

Cup Product: Detects obstructions to extending maps, sections. Essential in bundle theory.

Algebraic Geometry

Sheaf Cohomology: Cohomology of sheaves = foundation. Computes geometric invariants.

String Theory

Cohomology Classes: Background fields (B-fields, RR-fields) = cohomology classes. Topology affects physics.

De Rham Cohomology

Differential Forms: For manifolds, H^n_{dR}(M) ‚âÖ H^n(M; ‚Ñù). Bridge topology ‚Üî analysis.

üß© Exercises

Cochains

  1. Dual: If C_n = ‚Ñ§¬≥, what is C^n?

  2. Coboundary: Verify Œ¥¬≤ = 0 using ‚àÇ¬≤ = 0.

  1. Point: Verify H^n(pt) = ‚Ñ§ (n=0), 0 (n>0).

  2. Composition: Verify (f ‚àò g)^* = g^* ‚àò f^*.

Cup Product

  1. Torus: Verify a ‚à™ b ‚â† 0 but a ‚à™ a = 0 trong H^*(T¬≤).

  2. Commutativity: Œ± ‚àà H^1, Œ≤ ‚àà H^2. Compute Œ± ‚à™ Œ≤ vs Œ≤ ‚à™ Œ±.

Ring Structure

  1. Sphere: Verify H^*(S¬≤) ‚âÖ ‚Ñ§[x]/(x¬≤).

  2. Product: Compute H^*(S¬π √ó S¬π) as ring.

Universal Coefficient

  1. Apply: X v·ªõi H‚ÇÅ(X) = ‚Ñ§/3‚Ñ§. Compute H^1(X; ‚Ñ§).

  2. Torsion: Why H^1(‚ÑùP¬≤; ‚Ñ§) = 0 even though H‚ÇÅ = ‚Ñ§/2‚Ñ§?

Poincar√© Duality

  1. Verify: Poincar√© Duality for S¬≥ explicitly.

  2. Surface: Œ£_g genus g. Verify H^1(Œ£_g) ‚âÖ H‚ÇÅ(Œ£_g) via duality.

Advanced

  1. ‚ÑùP¬≤ Coefficients: Compute H^*(‚ÑùP¬≤; ‚Ñ§/2‚Ñ§) v√† verify ring structure.

  2. ‚ÑÇP¬≤: Research H^*(‚ÑÇP¬≤). (Answer: ‚Ñ§[x]/(x¬≥), x ‚àà H¬≤.)

Reflection

  1. Why Cohomology?: List advantages over homology.

  2. Ring Power: Give example where ring structure distinguishes spaces homology groups can‚Äôt.

  3. Contravariance: Explain intuition for reverse direction c·ªßa cohomology maps.

  4. Cup Product Geometry: Research how cup product relates to intersection theory.

üìö Further Reading

  • Hatcher, ¬ß3: Comprehensive cohomology theory
  • Bott & Tu: Differential forms perspective
  • Bredon, Chapter V: Advanced topics
  • Milnor & Stasheff: Characteristic Classes

üéì Summary

Cohomology = dual theory with rich structure:

‚úÖ Cochains C^n: Hom(C_n, G) (dual)
‚úÖ Coboundary Œ¥: C^n ‚Üí C^{n+1} (Œ¥¬≤ = 0)
‚úÖ Cohomology H^n: ker(Œ¥) / im(Œ¥)
‚úÖ Contravariant: f induces f^* (reverse direction)
‚úÖ Cup Product ‚à™: Multiplication H^p ‚äó H^q ‚Üí H^{p+q}
‚úÖ Ring H^*(X): Graded ring invariant
‚úÖ Universal Coefficient: Relates H^n to H_n (Ext appears!)
‚úÖ Poincar√© Duality: H^k(M) ‚âÖ H_{n-k}(M) (manifolds)

ƒêi·ªÉm ch√≠nh:

  • Cohomology = more refined than homology
  • Cup product = powerful geometric invariant
  • Ring structure detects subtle topology
  • Contravariance = natural for duality
  • Foundation for characteristic classes

Geometric intuition:

  • Cochains = ‚Äúmeasurements‚Äù on chains
  • Cup product = intersection of cycles
  • Ring structure = multiplicative invariant
  • Poincar√© Duality = orthogonal complement

Practical wisdom:

  • Use ‚Ñ§/2‚Ñ§ coefficients for non-orientable spaces
  • Cup product often easiest to compute via duality
  • Ring structure more powerful than groups alone
  • Essential for bundles, obstruction theory

Chapter 07 Complete! Ch√∫ng ta mastered:

  • Cohomology (dual, ring structure)

‚ÄúCohomology: where duality becomes multiplication, and topology becomes algebra.‚Äù

üéØ Master cohomology! The ring structure is revolutionary. üéØ

üîó Exact Sequences Review

1. Definition

ƒê·ªãnh nghƒ©a (Exact Sequence):
M·ªôt d√£y c√°c abelian groups v√† c√°c homomorphisms:

\[\cdots \to A_{n+1} \xrightarrow{f_{n+1}} A_n \xrightarrow{f_n} A_{n-1} \to \cdots\]

‚ÄúOutput c·ªßa map tr∆∞·ªõc = kernel c·ªßa map sau.‚Äù Tr·ª±c gi√°c h√¨nh h·ªçc l√† m·ªôt exact sequence l√† m·ªôt d√£y c√°c groups v√† maps sao cho image c·ªßa m·ªói map b·∫±ng kernel c·ªßa map ti·∫øp theo‚Äîƒëi·ªÅu n√†y ƒë·∫£m b·∫£o r·∫±ng th√¥ng tin ƒë∆∞·ª£c ‚Äúb·∫£o to√†n‚Äù qua d√£y.

C√°c v√≠ d·ª•:

Tr·ª±c gi√°c: $B$ ‚Äúk·∫øt h·ª£p‚Äù $A$ v√† $C$. ƒêi·ªÅu n√†y c√≥ nghƒ©a l√† $B$ c√≥ th·ªÉ ƒë∆∞·ª£c hi·ªÉu nh∆∞ m·ªôt c√°ch k·∫øt h·ª£p $A$ v√† $C$ l·∫°i v·ªõi nhau, v·ªõi $A$ ƒë∆∞·ª£c nh√∫ng v√†o $B$ v√† $B$ ƒë∆∞·ª£c √°nh x·∫° l√™n $C$.

Khi ƒë√≥: $B \cong A \oplus C$ (direct sum). ƒê√¢y l√† m·ªôt tr∆∞·ªùng h·ª£p ƒë·∫∑c bi·ªát‚Äîn·∫øu exact sequence ‚Äúsplit‚Äù, th√¨ $B$ l√† t·ªïng tr·ª±c ti·∫øp c·ªßa $A$ v√† $C$.

2. Long Exact Sequence

C_‚Ä¢: ‚Ä¶ ‚Üí C_{n+1} ‚Üí C_n ‚Üí C_{n-1} ‚Üí ‚Ä¶

üéØ Mayer-Vietoris Theorem

1. Statement

ƒê·ªãnh l√Ω (Mayer-Vietoris):

\[\cdots \to H_n(A \cap B) \xrightarrow{\phi_n} H_n(A) \oplus H_n(B) \xrightarrow{\psi_n} H_n(X) \xrightarrow{\partial_n} H_{n-1}(A \cap B) \to \cdots\]

üéì Summary

üî∫ Standard Simplex

  • Ho·∫°t ƒë·ªông cho B·∫§T K·ª≤ kh√¥ng gian $X$‚Äîkh√¥ng c·∫ßn c·∫•u tr√∫c ƒë·∫∑c bi·ªát
  • Th∆∞·ªùng l√† v√¥ h·∫°n (ngay c·∫£ ƒë·ªëi v·ªõi c√°c kh√¥ng gian h·ªØu h·∫°n!)‚Äîc√≥ v√¥ s·ªë c√°ch √°nh x·∫° standard simplex v√†o m·ªôt kh√¥ng gian

Key insight: V√¥ s·ªë singular simplices l√† OK v√¨ ch√∫ng ta ch·ªâ quan t√¢m ƒë·∫øn c√°c t·ªïng h√¨nh th·ª©c (chains) v√† c·∫•u tr√∫c ƒë·∫°i s·ªë. ƒêi·ªÅu n√†y c√≥ nghƒ©a l√† m·∫∑c d√π c√≥ v√¥ s·ªë singular simplices, ch√∫ng ta ch·ªâ l√†m vi·ªác v·ªõi c√°c t·ªïng h·ªØu h·∫°n c·ªßa ch√∫ng, v√† ƒëi·ªÅu n√†y ƒë·ªß ƒë·ªÉ x√°c ƒë·ªãnh homology groups.

üîó Singular Chain Complex

1. Chain Groups

T·ªïng h·ªØu h·∫°n (m·∫∑c d√π c√≥ v√¥ s·ªë $\sigma_i$ t·ªìn t·∫°i). ƒêi·ªÅu n√†y c√≥ nghƒ©a l√† m·ªói chain l√† m·ªôt t·ªï h·ª£p tuy·∫øn t√≠nh h·ªØu h·∫°n c·ªßa c√°c singular simplices v·ªõi c√°c h·ªá s·ªë nguy√™n. Trong b√†i n√†y we systematically develop two fundamental constructions. Subspace topology defines induced topology on subsets‚Äîmost natural way to make subset inherit topological structure. üìê ƒê·ªãnh nghƒ©a H√¨nh th·ª©c

4. Product Topology (Finite)

  • (B2): (U‚ÇÅ √ó V‚ÇÅ) ‚à© (U‚ÇÇ √ó V‚ÇÇ) = (U‚ÇÅ ‚à© U‚ÇÇ) √ó (V‚ÇÅ ‚à© V‚ÇÇ) ‚àà ‚Ñ¨ ‚úì

5. Projections

8. Tychonoff‚Äôs Theorem
